climbs.name: Welcome To Rondoland (aka Glenda's Crack)
climbs.fa: Jay Smith, Robert Finley, Rondo Powell 1989

content.description:
Scramble up a ramp to belay. Begin up and right, then move left with the crack. Power, balance, and technique all come into play as one moves past the dwindling crack. Continue back left as the crack reappears.

Without HB brass, this route would deserve an "R" rating; even with, it may deserve a "PG".
content.protection: Gear to 2".  Thin tcu's/aliens and brass a must! Gear anchor.

climbs.name: There Is No Place Like Home

content.description: Climb the face past bolts.  The guidebooks indicate three bolts, but we only found two.  There is a long runout on 5.8/5.9 moves on the upper part of the climb, with somewhat loose holds.
content.protection: two or three bolts plus gear for an anchor
content.location: This route starts on a ledge, near the finish to The Answer.

content.description:
Doug and I climbed this in threatening weather. Exiting from the dihedral was a flake of rock that was a perfect handhold to help pull you out. When exiting, I pulled on that flake and it came off (I have some before/during/after pics of the FA). I don't believe that it was climbed prior to our ascent as this flake would obviously have been touched prior, had the route been climbed. Thus I dispute the "Answer" FA claim. If the "Answer" team can show me photos of that flake there during their ascent...I'll acquiesce and accept their claimed FA and name.

And as a historical sidenote, it was my name that stuck to this formation and have always thought it one of the better names I came up with. I only wish it was a better "dome." Haha.

We climbed "Storm Riders" to explore elements of the formation for other ascents and walked off to the west.
content.location: Large, obvious, left-facing flake/dihedral/overhang. Called "The Answer" in Vogel's guide.

climbs.name: Question, The
climbs.fa: James Weger and Aleida Matthies, April 1988

content.description: The crux of this route is in the first 15 feet.  You can do a wide stem off a boulder to one side, or a wall on the other, or avoid the stems entirely, making it 5.10D.  Hand jams lead to crux rattly finger jams.  The upper part of the route is 5.6.
content.location: Start just right of The Answer, at a vertical to overhanging crack.

climbs.name: Pay No Attention To The Man Behind The Curtain
climbs.fa: Roger Linfield and Dave Patterson, January 1999

content.description: Easy but loose climbing leads to a short crux offwidth/squeeze chimney.  Inch your way up this wide section until it narrows to fist jams, and then continue to the top.  It is possible to lieback the crux at about the same 5.10A difficulty level.
content.location: This climb starts 40 feet up and right from the start of Honey, or about 60 feet up and right from the finish to The Answer.  Climb The Question or The Answer as an approach.

content.description: Fun and varied, this may be the best pitch on the crag. A couple of moves off the ledge gain the bottom of a left-arching splitter crack. The crack ends at about the half way point, above fun face climbing on good edges leads to the top. Recommend doing this in cool to cold weather as the route name is a reference to the bee hive in the upper section of the crack. In cold weather the bees will be gone or dormant/docile.
content.protection: Std rack to 3". Face above the crack is protectable with wires.
content.location:
Starts on the right side of the ledge/alcove where

Storm Riders (aka The Answer)

tops out. Climbing

The Answer

(5.9) would be the best way to approach. Walk off climbers' left.
